contentrichtext.text: {{about||the computer|Iamus (computer)|the album|Iamus (album)}} In [[Greek mythology]], '''Iamus''' was the son of [[Evadne]], a daughter of [[Poseidon]], sired by [[Apollo (god)|Apollo]]. Shamed by her pregnancy, Evadne exposed the child to the elements. He survived, as two snakes were feeding him with honey. He was then found alive lying among violets, and was named Iamus (from ίον, "violet") by Evadne. When he grew up, he descended into the waters of [[Alpheios]] and invoked Poseidon, his grandfather, and Apollo, his father, asking them to reveal his destiny to him. Apollo instructed him to go to Olympia. Granted the gift of prophecy by Apollo, he founded the [[Iamidae]], a family of priests from [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]].<ref>[[Pindar]], Olympian Ode 4</ref><ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 4. 2. 3</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mythindex.com/greek-mythology/I/Iamus.html Myth Index - Iamus] [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Offspring of Apollo]] [[Category:Elean mythology]] [[Category:Mythological Greek seers]] {{Greek-myth-stub}} {{Greek-deity-stub}}
